Reviews.Title: S8100 was worth the wait!
Reviews.Author: Mike C. Carlson "Mike Carlson"
Reviews.Content: OK, I was really wanting the RED Nikon S8100 but apparently only black is available unless you buy it directly from Nikon. I decided to go black because I live in Oregon where there is no sales tax, and Nikon was going to tax me and add $10 to the shipping. Black isn't all that bad looking anyway and it matches my Cooler Master HAF-X PC case.I'm upgrading from a Sony DSC-V1.  The size of the Nikon is a hair wider, a hair shorter and about half as thick.  The DSC-V1 had a po-pup flash in the same area as the S8100 so I was used to holding the camera the correct way already.  For those of you that can't think outside the box, the proper way to hold this camera is to make a gun with your left hand, thumb pointing up, then bend your wrist so the gun is pointing to your right, then place the camera in the gun. RTFM. This tip is printed (and pictured) in the quick start booklet that came with the camera. Once you get used to it, you won't mind pop-up flashes at all.  The only issue you will have is when your dense friends take pictures of you with it and hold the flash down, not knowing any better.The downgrade from the S8000's 14 megapixel CCD to the S8100's 12 megapixel CMOS sensor is no downgrade whatsoever. Megapixels are nearly irrelevant to point and shoot cameras above 12 anyway, and the image quality increase, and low light shooting improvements you get with the CMOS sensor EASILY trump a 2 megapixel increase. I am continuing to be surprised how good my pictures keep turning out, in all light levels.The 10x optical zoom is great, but what is amazing is how clean the digital zoom is beyond that. I am used to fuzzy or blurry shots when using the digital zoom, but this camera somehow gets around that. The placement of the zoom lever forces you to use your right forefinger instead of your thumb which I'm used to. It felt kind of odd at first, but makes complete logical sense from an ergonomic point of view when you are holding the camera properly. On the opposite side, the macro function floored me. For a point and shoot camera, I never expected a macro this good. It macro shoots better than my Cannon DSLR. I can rest the lens up against the object I'm shooting and the image will still focus good.The LCD screen on the back is a typical 3" screen, but a very untypically high quality resolution. It has the highest resolution screen of any point and shoot I could find. You can really see the detail of what you are about to shoot with it. It's bright and the colors are accurate.The 1080p video this camera produces is better than I expected. Far better. You can use the zoom feature while rolling AND take stills simultaneously. It also records in stereo sound. Great stuff.Some people complained that this camera is still a bit too large for their liking.  If it was any smaller that it is now, you would not be able to hold it without accidentally pressing a button or something, and it fits in my pocket just fine. Those people must have toothpick fingers or don't realize that size much smaller than the S8100 really isn't much of an advantage unless you are some kind of top secret spy or something.The camera has all the basic features you would want, and several that are kind of neat. Manual on the fly brightness, hue, and vividness adjustments can be handy, the skin softening feature turns your subjects into super models, and the ISO sensitivity range is above average. It has a wind noise reduction option while taking video, and all the features you would use the most are easily and quickly accessible.I know I'm sounding like a Nikon fanboy now but I'm just so happy with this camera. The only thing I can think of I don't care for is the rubber stop that plugs the USB port on the bottom of the camera. I prefer a flip door, but this is just my preference.It comes with surprisingly good full version photo editing software, and even a panoramic stitching program that I've yet to try. The full manual is on a CD that comes with it though I prefer a book to look at. The start-up speed (power on to photo ready) is just under 2 seconds. Holy cow batman!One feature that I haven't taken advantage of yet but look really useful in action shooting is the high-speed shooting at five full resolution frames at up to 10 frames'per'second, and  a pre'shooting cache that records up to two shots before the shutter'release is fully pressed. This will really make it easy to get the action shot you really want. The other feature that I'm very impressed by is the advanced Night Landscape mode which combines a series of five consecutive shots taken at a fast shutter speed into a single image with reduced noise when taking hand held shots.  Dark backgrounds turn out very visible without over lighting the subject. Very cool technology idea.In summery, I feel like the $299 I paid for the Nikon S8100 is very justified. DSLRs should be nervous that these point and shooters will start stealing their market considering the lower price, quality and technology improvements. Nikon has a winner!

Reviews.Title: Worth the Wait
Reviews.Author: steven a. silver
Reviews.Content: I've been waiting since late summer for the Canon 4500 and the Nikon s8100 to be released. The Canon came out first, about three weeks ago, and I immediately bought one.I played with it for a week and decided it just didn't live up to my expectations (in auto mode: flash too bright and uncontrolable, images NOT razor sharp, 36mm lens too narrow). I returned the Canon 4500 and ordered the Nikon s8100 last week.  What a difference! If picture quality is your main concern (which is, of course, every photographers main concern) this little baby really shines. In auto mode, images are razor sharp and super bright with or without flash and throughout the full range of the zoom. I don't know if it's the Nikor lense or the auto focus system but these pictures are superior to any point and shoot I've ever played with. The Cannons image quality was similar to a lesser priced digital point and shoot. The Nikon is a full step above this.  There are a few small negatives: the worst being the rediculous placement of the pop-up flash. Each time I've attempted to take my first flash picture of the day my finger has been over the flash which prevents it from fully opening. At least a note comes on the monitor which tells you that the flash is not fully up. Once the flash is up it stays up until you manually push it down, so it's not like this problem occurs every time you take a flash photo. I'm sure I'll find a different way to hold the camera to avoid this annoying problem...but it's certainly not a deal breaker.  This camera does not have as many manual controls as the Canon 4500 but if I want to get super creative I'll use my SLR.  It's also a tad thicker than I'd like (about the size of a cigarette pack) but can still fit in your pocket. However, both the lens and the monitor are not recessed or protected in any way and scratches will be hard to avoid. I'm using a soft suede pouch when it's in my pocket to protect it.  Overall, I'm very happy with the Nikon s8100 and highly reccomend it for anyone looking for super high quality photos in an easy to use reasonably priced camera.UPDATE: Took camera out for first extended shoot on Halloween night. Did not perform as well as I'd hoped for. All pix shot in low lite (outdoors, night) in auto mode with flash. Flash way too bright to the point where some pix were washed out with too much lite. Will try previous commenters suggestion of playing with the limited manual controls to attempt to correct this problem. Images NOT as sharp as day time shots without flash.Will update again very soon as I'm taking out the camera again today for day AND night shots.

Reviews.Title: Great Still photos & features, poor focusing in video & zoom noise
Reviews.Author: Saibal
Reviews.Content: UPDATE: I have returned the camera today after observing two issues that are dealbreaker for me. We finally had a bright sunny day today and I took some videos to compare against my 3 year old Canon Powershot TX1 that shoots 720p. I also received my mini-HDMI cable so I could watch the video on my 42" LCD TV directly without post-processing thru Apple TV box.ISSUE #1: The video keeps going out of focus while I zoom or pan - whether I set center, weighted focus and/or single AF or continuous AF. The recorded video looks really bad. On the other hand my TX1 stays rock steady with the focus.ISSUE #2: There is a loud zoom motor noise that gets recorded in the clip. I initially thought that continuous AF or Image Stabilization is causing the noise. I put the camera on a tripod and disabled continuous AF and the noise remained and it was clearly there when I operated the zoom.The still photography feature of the camera is stunning, but video is important for me as well as I want to carry only one camera on my travels.I love the 3" LCD on this camera, but the two issues pushed me over the edge.Original review below:This is my 1st Nikon. I have always purchased Canon ever since I used a Canon A1 35mm film SLR nearly 30 yrs back. I own a Canon Digital SLR, Canon DV Cam, Canon Powershot TX1. Most of my photography during travel/vacation has been with the TX1 shooting both stills as well as 720p Video which I edit on my Mac and then stream thru my Apple TV.I have been looking forward to replacing my TX1 with a camera that is:- compact like TX1- bigger and better LCD screen (TX1 has very tiny one)- shoots 1080p with full optical zoom (not handicapped like Canon has done with all their 1080p shooting compact cameras that don't allow optical zooming during video recording)- good range of optical zoom- image stabilized lens- reasonable number of pixels- better low light shooting- shoot moving objects- separate shutter button and video recording buttons - this is very useful when the subject is not waiting for you to fiddle with the rotary selector as with most cameras (except for TX1 which had this feature).It is important for me give all this preamble to relate to what my expectations were from this camera.Gave up on Canon finally, looked into Panasonic ZX7 - didn't like the reviews and waited patiently for the release of Nikon S8100. Received it today. Have taken some shots and here is my first impression.1. I am happy with the image quality of the stills2. Great quality of 1080p video (haven't tried the 720p mode as yet)3. Optical zoom is very good (the rate of zooming slows down during video recording)4. Controls are simple to use5. Very fast focus response6. Very fast start time7. Very good image stabilization8. Face detection works very well (even on images on TV)9. Very good build quality (feels robust) - just like my TX1Only negative: The position of the flash. It is the place where you would normally grip the camera with your left index finger. If the flash wasn't a pop up type, this could have been avoided.Overall, I am very happy with the camera. Will move on to try the remaining features in the next few days. Have to get hold of the mini-HDMI cable to test the direct to TV playback of 1080p video.

Reviews.Title: The best camera I've ever own
Reviews.Author: Optional "Optional"
Reviews.Content: I usually don't write review.  But I'm writing this now because of the unfair reviews due to user errors, not the camera. I was born in a photography family that has been in the business since the 60s.  I do know how to work a camera, I know what a correct setting is for different light situations.  This is the BEST camera in its category I have ever own, and I've own a lot: Canon, Sony, Pentax, Panasonic, Nikon all in the same category and price range (at the time of its release). Although it's classified as "point & shoot", there are pre-set settings that you have to know when to use them and when NOT to use them.  So this is an advance point & shoot camera which requires user's knowledge to fully leverage its features. If you are NOT generally savvy with electronics & computers, don't buy this camera because you don't have the knowledge to leverage its features to your advantage, it would just be a piece of junk & a waste of money for you. But if you are, this is the BEST camera in its category.I took picture of a small printed picture, inside, no flash, low light, it came out looking almost close to the original.  I took pictures during family Thanksgiving dinner, again no flash, normal room light, the pictures came out perfect: clean, clear, vibrant, naturally light as you see with naked eyes.  I generally don't like using flash as it doesn't project the real natural light (this include super professional cameras).  So I'm extremely excited that this camera can capture indoor low light without flash, looking like what you see with naked eyes. With ALL of my previous cameras, this wasn't possible, the pictures would just come out lacking of color, a lot darker than what you see with naked eyes and grainy.Out door, the zoom is crisp without sacrificing the quality.  The color is rich, clarity is flawless without grain/noise (I do not use digital zoom, only optical zoom for best quality). Object from very far away coming out looking like you are standing right in front of it and take a picture.I haven't used the video feature because I don't use a picture camera as a video recorder.  I have a video recorder and I use it to record video.  I expect a camera just to be a perfect camera.  It's dumb to expect a camera to perform an exceptional job in video recording.

Reviews.Title: Nikon S8100 vs Canon SX210 performance comparison
Reviews.Author: lindguini
Reviews.Content: UPDATED 1/14/11:I was hoping to find a still/video camera that would give me the low light performance of my Fuji F20 and also allow me to avoid hauling around a separate HD camcorder.  My comparisons show that the low light photos from the S8100 handily out perform my Fuji F20 and by a good margin (which is no small feat considering that the 6MP Fuji F20/F30/F40 pretty much set the standard for low light performance in point-and-shoots).  If great low light photos are what you're after, the S8100 is very good (but there is a penalty for this performance as I explain below).  However, if you also want great low light video, the Nikon does not deliver.  In my two weeks of testing, I've determined that the Canon SX210 is the optimum choice if you want the best balance of low light photos and video.Here are my observations after two weeks of testing:NIKON S8100 PROS-Nice build quality and easy-to-handle design.  Feels like a pro-sumer $600 camera.-Outrageous 3-inch, 921K pixel LCD display --excellent clarity and detail.-Decent HD video in daytime lighting.-Powerful flash that provides excellent illumination at all zoom settings (no flash shadow at wide angle).-USB battery charging in camera (can connect to your PC to charge).NIKON S8100 CONS-No manual control except for +/-exposure compensation.-No brightness or white balance settings for video (versus Canon's excellent custom controls).-Videos are simply too dark in low lighting (the Canon wins by a landslide here)-Auto white balance is fooled by compact fluorescent lights (Canon's AWB is more reliable).-Camera prefers low ISO settings even in low light and this can cause motion blur.-Significant zoom motor noise during videos (versus the nearly silent Canon SX210 zoom)-Pop-up flash must be pushed back into camera body before stowing camera in case.-Camera beep and shutter release sound can only be turned on or off (no volume adjustment like Canon)CANON SX210 PROS-Very good low light video, video brightness control really boosts low light sensitivity.-Very good still photos, camera chooses higher ISO settings to reduce motion blur-Camera displays its ISO choice when you pre-focus (not possible with Nikon)-Extensive customization settings for every shooting mode (versus limited Nikon settings).-Widescreen LCD for full frame HD video display-Very good build quality-Pop up flash automatically raises or lowers when you power on/offCANON SX210 CONS-Body design makes for tricky handling (no rear thumb grip, smooth surfaces)-LCD is only 230K pixel (compared to the incredible Nikon 921K pixel display)-Still photo viewing area is much smaller on widescreen display-Overall still image quality is slightly noisier than Nikon but only if you're pixel peeping-Some flash shadow at the 28mm wide angle setting (disappears from 30mm on up)STILL PHOTO QUALITY COMPARISON:Photos in good lighting are comparable between the Nikon and Canon.  The Nikon has the least noise at higher ISO settings.  In low light, the Nikon really shines and if you take photos of non-moving subjects, the S8100 is your best choice.  However, there's a penalty for this performance:  the Nikon chooses very low ISO settings (and therefore low shutter speeds) to achieve low noise photos --not good if your subjects are moving (you'll get blur).  At high zoom, both cameras have to use lower shutter speeds and every super zoom camera suffers from this issue --it's the problem most people complain about when they try out their new cameras.  The only way to solve this problem is to either use the flash or set high ISO (something the Canon does automatically) in order to force the camera to select a higher shutter speed.  There is no other solution and no camera has yet been developed to solve this problem -it's a compromise of light, optics, and sensor sensitivity in compact camera bodies.  For all around shooting, the Canon is more reliable since it chooses higher ISO (and hence faster shutter speeds) to capture non-blurry images.  The Nikon's lower automatic ISO "choices" will result in more blurry shots indoors unless you use the flash.HD VIDEO QUALITY:Both cameras have very good HD video and excellent image stabilization in daytime lighting.  As with most super zoom compacts, focus lock in low light is a challenge but the Canon SX210 is better than the Nikon if you want faster focus lock during video.  in reality, the Canon operates more like a dedicated camcorder with all the tweaks and settings you can imagine --credit Canon's long history building camcorders.  Unfortunately, the Nikon operates as if video was a second thought feature and there's simply no way to improve its performance since there's no manual control.  The Canon's low light video brightness, focus speed, and silent zoom motor make for great video under all conditions.  Conversely, the Nikon's noisy zoom motor is recorded in videos and the camera simply can't provide bright, usable videos in low indoor lighting.  In low light, the Canon is in a league of its own.  If you're trying to video children or pets running back and forth quickly at close range to these cameras then you'll be disappointed in ANY super zoom compact camera you try.  The fact is the ultimate, magic "focus anywhere instantly" machine has not yet been invented.  However, as an alternative to lugging around a dedicated HD camcorder, the Canon SX210 is hard to beat for convenience and consistent HD video quality.OVERALL:I really, really wanted to keep the Nikon S8100.  It has superb handling quality, great low light still photos and an impressive 921K pixel display.  I have owned several Canon and Fuji digital cameras and have never seriously considered Nikon's point-and-shoot offerings until the introduction of the S8100.  However, the Nikon is not a well-rounded still/video camera.  It does a few things very well but fails at others.  The Canon SX210, on the other hand, is a much better performer at each end of the still photo and video spectrum.  The Nikon is great camera to hold and operate from a hardware standpoint, but the Canon simply out performs it when it comes to getting the best quality photos and videos under a wide range of shooting conditions.  After months of research and camera testing, no single camera does everything perfectly.  However, I believe the Canon SX210 provides the best balance of performance among its peers if you're looking for a pocketable, super-zoom camera to provide both good photos and HD video.UPDATE:  SPECIAL NOTE ON POP-UP FLASHA lot of people complain about the pop-up flash on super-zoom cameras since the flash is usually located on the top left corner of the camera body and occupies the space where you want to hold the camera.  Be advised that the pop-up flash is a physical necessity in order to move the flash far enough away from the camera so that the long, super-zoom lens doesn't cast a shadow on your subject when the flash fires.  If you really don't like the inconvenience of the pop-up flash then your only choice is a limited (7X or less) zoom camera or a bulkier SLR-type.  If you want a pocketable super-zoom, you'll just have to get used to this flash placement.  It may be a minor inconvenience at first, but in the end it's a non-issue and should not be the sole reason you give up on the incredible performance that compact, 14X zoom cameras like the SX210 have to offer.

Reviews.Title: Great zoom, very good Continuous
Reviews.Author: D. Larsen "Dianne"
Reviews.Content: I am primarily a DSLR user, but that is not always practical to carry around.  I enjoy skiing and snowmobiling in the winter, and a compact camera is much easier for those activities.  Additionally, I always carry a camera in my purse just in case the perfect shot comes up.  Almost all of my pictures are either landscape, or action (pets and sports).  I was actually researching for a camera as a gift for someone else when I found that there are a few cameras now that provide a large optical zoom capability AND the continuous/burst modes.  These 2 features in combination in a compact camera exactly meet my requirements. So far I am very pleased with the pictures from this camera.  I've posted several photos at this Amazon camera link for people to view that demonstrate the features most important to me.  There are 2 pictures with an Airstream trailer, one at no zoom, the other at 10x zoom.  That zoom is amazing.  Fantastic clarity and detail (even when I zoom in on my computer).  The continuous shooting is not as good as my DSLR, but still very acceptable.  I added a couple of photos of my cat and golden retriever taken in the continuous mode (12MP*).  These photos demonstrate shots from very slow motion up to very fast motion.  I printed a few shots as 8.5 x 11, and the printed pictures came out extremely clear.  I'm still testing it out, but so far its definitely a keeper!

Reviews.Title: So far a GOOD solid VERY SMALL (for 10x) Zoom Auto Point and Shoot - But doesn't over come the laws of physics. (Darn!)
Reviews.Author: FlickerKing
Reviews.Content: OK, so I bought this camera from Amazon, great service from them, only had this camera 2 days so this is just a first impression.  Usually I wait for the reviews and buy then but the features on this looked good and besides, its Christmas! (almost).  This Nikon s8100 a just a little bigger and heavier (10x Zoom) than the Canon IS1100, 1200, 1300, 1400s (3x Zooms), needs a "slightly" bigger case.  Camera startup is reasonably speedy, something less than 3 seconds from start/focus/take picture in low light ( faster outside).  Good enough for me. Very little shutter lag, comparable or better than other good digitals I've owned (Canon A710, 1100is). Focus is fast and accurate.  This is a next gen camera so it should do all of that stuff well and it does.  Weight: yes it weighs a little more but feels solid.  Guess Nikon hasn't figured out how to make a good  10x zoom lens weigh less than a ¼ gram, darn those guys!.  Focusing: yes when I zoom in and try to focus closer than the lens physically can get it won't focus (10x has to be something over 10' or so).  Another law of physics Nikon is unable to overcome, darn those guys again!  Low light pics: very nice.  Low light video also very good, but there is one setting in video the 1080 without the star where the video looks dull. Don't know why, set it on the star 1080(default) and leave it.  No manual controls: I didn't buy this for the manual controls (its a point & shoot remember, get your Binford 5000 25pound mucho $$$ rig out for the tricky stuff), I just want to whip it out,  take pictures and video, and it does that well.  Pictures and video look very good, better than my other cameras.  The video focus will hunt a TINY bit when zooming, but, this camera WILL zoom during video, unlike others.  Low light video is good but the more you zoom the less light you get (gee! That's like all my other cameras EVER, and its a 10x zoom, not 3x or 4x) So, video  works  good when you compare zoom distance to light collection.  Auto scene mode doesn't pick the right scene indoors in low light (wants to use night landscape), use Regular Auto in that situation.  Auto Scene works OK so far otherwise.  Flash is good and fairly powerful for a small unit, exposure mostly about right. You just need to hold it differently than other cameras for the flash to pop up on the top left side, one handed pics (for right handers), no problem.  Battery life, not as good as others, but OK.  Use the USB cable to charge the battery in the camera,  4hrs, OR, get an extra charger and battery and do it that way, you HAVE A CHOICE with the s8100.  Oh, BTW, (as others point out) the USB cover FEELs flimsy (I couldn't really care less about this... it works).  Haven't found any large flaws yet. Just get out there and take pictures!

Reviews.Title: Absolutely PHENOMENAL
Reviews.Author: D. Reynolds "Steph"
Reviews.Content: I'm not a professional photographer, but I do know my way around a camera.  I've never owned a compact camera anywhere near as fantastic as this camera.  Every single thing it does is a mini miracle.The zoom is seamless and it focuses faster and clearer throughout the entire range than many SLR lenses I've used. The new sensor is unbelievable.  A sign of a good camera is its capability to take pictures in the dark.  That's something I always look for when buying a new camera.  This camera has new technology for its "night portrait" mode.  It actually takes a picture without flash (so as to capture the light behind you) and then takes a flash picture.  It then combines the two shots giving a true to life image of the the person and background.  You can't tell that it takes two pictures because it all only takes the time of a normal flash picture.  Same goes for "night landscape" mode.  I tested it by taking a flash-free picture of my kitchen at night with all of the lights in the house off.  In the photo, you can actually see the oven and refrigerator and even read the clock on the oven and microwave. And it's not even noisy (grainy).It has many advanced features for a compact, such as the ability to view a histogram and to look at the information of pictures you've already taken, like the ISO sensitivity used.  Very handy if you like how a picture turned out and want to try to repeat the results.And then there's the video.  While I mainly bought this camera for its photo capabilities, there is no denying that this little guy makes fantastic videos.  Extremely clear and realistic.  The sound could be a bit better, but it's certainly not bad enough to complain.  If you're recording something silent, you can hear the zoom a little, but isn't that true with all video cameras?  This camera also has a great feature for slow motion videos.  I've never been so amused as I have been while trying to find things to record in slow-mo.So, in summary.  The photos are crystal clear and true to color.  The new night shooting capabilities are the absolute best I've seen in a compact camera.  It has 10x optical zoom plus around 4x digital. And it records full 1080p HD video. AND it's all in a cute little compact package.  How can you beat that?Oh, and the color of the red camera is the most gorgeous shade of red I've ever seen.  The photo here definitely doesn't do it justice.If you decide to buy one of these cameras, I hope you enjoy it as much as I do!

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera w/Great Potential
Reviews.Author: Loujul
Reviews.Content: When looking for a camera to replace my old Canon SD870IS, I wanted a camera that would work well in low light.  I chose the Nikon Coolpix S8100 and the Canon SD4500IS to compare.  It took a lot of research between the two, but finally I went with the Nikon.  I'm so happy with my choice.  First it's an easy camera to pick up out of the box and use.  The dial on top is simply marked and it even has two scene icons, one for those of us who are challenged in selecting what we're actually looking at and one for those who can actually distinguish between people, kids, pets, and landscapes.  The video record button is located on the right upper corner of the backside which is a nice feature for instant recording.  There are a lot of features available to learn to use and the manual covers all.  The test for me was a party in a restaurant which was dimly lighted.  I was amazed at how well the photos came, with and without the flash. It certainly passed the lighting test.  The only downside for me is the flash is a pop-up on the top of the left side where I always rest my fingers.  I have to learn to hold my hand off the flash.  I love, love, love this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: Antonpd
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my wife and she's loving it.  We were looking for a really good p&s; with a great auto mode and we narrowed our choices to the Nikon 8100, Sony HX5V, ZS5 and Canon SX210is.  We decided to go with the Nikon because of the 1080p video, cmos chip for lowlight shooting and 914k pixel LCD.  The pics come out beautiful but you may need to reshoot sometimes due to flash overexposure or blurriness in low light (pretty standard with these mega zoom compacts).  The video is also great just be sure to get a class 6 SDHC card or better and change the options to HQ video and pics(for some reason Nikon defaults to the lower quality).  I also recommend not using the continuous AF (you'll hear clicking sounds in the video).I'm not crazy about Nikon not supplying a battery charger, instead you charge the battery in the camera with the usb cord.  Come on Nikon!  It also doesn't automatically reposition pics taken in portrait mode (you'll need to put the camera upright to review).  Hopefully they fix that with updated firmware.  I wish the wide zoom (30mm) was better but it's ok.  The menus could be a little more intuitive and a printed manual would have been great (it's on a disk like all other camera's these days).  Finally, the software Nikon supplies is lousy.  Come to think of it, all photo software from camera manufacturers is lousy.  Just go with Picasa for photo organizing and light editing and Photoscape for more robust editing.  Both free.Anyway, it may sound like I'm nitpicking but it is a pretty good p&s.;  A few firmware fixes will make this camera shine.  I recommend it for someone wanting a simple to use camera, great pics, low light, 10x zoom and stereo 1080p video.  If you want manual controls look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera With Numerous Small Downsides
Reviews.Author: Alexander C. Zorach "Alex Zorach"
Reviews.Content: After using a Canon for a number of years, I was pushed away from Canon by the fact that their newer cameras have an unusually slow continuous shooting mode.After sampling a large number of cameras currently in the $200-300 price range (as of several weeks before writing this review, when I purchased the camera), I settled on this one as there was simply no contender: no other camera, even significantly bulkier ones, offered the same combination of low-light, no-flash performance with general all-purpose quality.I have been VERY HAPPY with my purchase.  I think this camera offers unparalleled value in its category.  However, it has a few minor downsides which are minor, but regular annoyances.I'll start with the strengths.  As I see it the benefits are:(1) Small size--small enough to fit, in the case, in a large pocket, or out of the case, in a much smaller one.  Convenient case by the way!(2) Ease of use - it doesn't matter if you're used to another brand of pocket camera before: this one is extremely intuitive and easy to pick up.(3) OUTSTANDING low-light no-flash performance.  I can't emphasize this point enough: this is one of the main reasons why I bought the camera.  ISO 400 and 800 work very well: 400 is especially sharp.  There's an option for 1600 and 3200, and while I use them infrequently as they're nosier, I'm glad they're an option.(4) Image stabilization works really well, which I'm sure contributes to (3), but it also contributes to low shutter-speed far-zoomed-out pics as well.  Taking pictures of stationary targets, the camera handles gracefully down to 1/5th of a second, which I find absolutely remarkable.(5) This camera takes very, very good photos.  I think Nikon put a really good sensor in this camera, creating a balanced overall package rather than just inflating the megapixel and zoom rating the way some brands do.  There are other cameras on the market that I tested, including some from canon, that have "more" zoom and "more" megapixels but when you take photos side-by-side with this one, they come out less sharp--both when looking at closeups and when looking at the farthest out optical zoom.(6) Face recognition actually works.  I don't really care about this, but it's kinda fun and is a bonus.(7) Quick startup time.  Things in general are fast, except for two problems which I discuss below.  Quick time between photos, surprisingly quick flash cycling even.Caveats / Downsides: (These are all relatively minor complaints, not deal-breakers, although they're all things that are annoyances that I notice on a regular basis.)(1) ISO speed, which I change VERY frequently, requires going into the menu to change.  This is very cumbersome.(2) ... [EDIT:] addressed in comment, thanks!(3) Flash performance is relatively poor, especially in contrast to everything else about this camera.  Flash photos tend to have exceptionally poor color, relative to how well the camera does everything else.  Also, the auto mode really doesn't handle the flash gracefully--you need to fidget with things to get sharp photos.  Since I don't like using a flash, it's not a big downside, but I do want to point out that this camera really lags behind in this area.  Sometimes if you just point-and-shoot in auto mode, and take a flash photo, the result can be pretty awful...either bad lighting, too grainy, and the biggest problem, terrible color balance.  You can learn how to work with the flash but it takes adjustment and fidgeting and you can't just expect to take good flash photos out of the box.  The only good thing about the flash is that it cycles very quickly.(4) Writing images, even with a high speed memory card, is very slow.  If you take a number of photos even in moderately quick succession, and then close the camera, you often have to wait several seconds, which is a bit annoying.  Deleting images is even slow.(5) Continuous shooting mode, while very fast, only supports 5 photos at once.  This is really not enough for me.  Writing in continuous mode can be very slow, and you can't shoot again until it's done--the wait is about 12 seconds at the highest resolution.  By bumping down to 2048x1536 you can dramatically speed this up to 5 sec, and you can get a really quick cycling by using the tiny 640x480 resolution.(6) Perhaps a bit overzealous on the noise correction.  Sometimes when you edit out noise, information is lost, and when I really zoom in on the photos produced at low ISO's, I think some sharpness has often been lost, and I wish the camera would leave these photos grainier, as it's always possible to edit them (sometimes better than the camera could itself) after the fact, but it's not possible to get back what's lost..So, bottom line?  Excellent camera.  No real contenders in its size / price range.  However, not perfect, and it could be substantially improved.  Some of the downsides are things that

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: hydroman72
Reviews.Content: The camera is great.  I'm not giving it a 5 star because of 3 things.  1 - it's not very user friendly, there are hundreds of things that this camera can do but you'll need to be a daily user to engrain all of the features to use them.  Granted this camera can do a lot, but most of the time people will only use the auto modes.2 - The video slow motion is a great idea, but for some reason, you can't use it at night.  Even in a well lit area, it seems that the aperature get's very small so the result is a dark video.  You'll need bright sunlight to use the slow motion feature.  Can someone explain this?3 - Compact, if you're looking for a compact camera, better buy something with less features.  You'll probably be shooting in auto anyway so sacrifice the features and go smaller.  This camera is bulky to be carried in you pants pocket or a small purse.  Also because Nikon's lens cover (my description) has multi panels, it can be accidently opened, so you probably buy a small case which will add more bulk.As for the camera, it shoots great pictures and the flash is much more powerful then the compact point and shoot.  I know the popup flash is a bothersome but you get use to it.  And if you know you're going to use the flash, just block the sensor prior to shooting so the flash pops up, then position your fingers to avoid the flash.

Reviews.Title: "Lens Error" after 5 weeks
Reviews.Author: Kluya
Reviews.Content: My parents own this camera, and I was impressed by the quality of their pictures.  I bought the coolpix S8100 new on April 1st.  I was amazed at how easy it is to take good pictures - even on standard settings.  I brought it to Cancun and got compliments from everybody on my pictures.  The quality is outstanding for a point and shoot camera.  My only complaint was the popup flash is located in an annoying place.  It's where people commonly rest their left index finger when taking pictures.  I got used to it pretty quickly.5 weeks after buying the camera, I brought it to take pictures of a wedding venue.  After taking a picture, the lens wouldn't close.  There was an error on the screen that said "lens error".  I went on Nikon's site and tried all of the troubleshooting for "lens error".  Unfortunately it's outside of its return window, so I called Nikon.I have to send it to them (on my dime) and they will decide whether or not to fix it.  They say I have to package it in a different box than the box it came in, and I have to pay for UPS shipping and the recommend I pay for insurance.They can blame the lens error on the user for dropping it, and not cover it under warranty.  Unfortunately I did not drop or damage the camera.  I take care of my things, especially my electronics.  This is unacceptable for a 1 month old camera.  After reading other negative reviews on this camera, I learned this "lens error" is a common problem.I'm giving it 2 stars instead of 1 because it's a great camera when it works.  Beware and buy extra insurance or a protection plan if you want this camera.

Reviews.Title: I love this Camera!
Reviews.Author: lillyb33
Reviews.Content: I just got this camera for my birthday and I have to say it is amazing! I love its size because it fits in my purse perfectly for when I go out with friends. It is so easy to use and when you really want to capture something in the moment it turns on fast enough and snaps the shot in record time. Pictures come out so clean and clear even in the dark lighting when I'm out at night. I have used it in bars, houses, outside and every shot looks well lit regardless of how dark it maybe. You may have to get used to the place of the pop up flash but after using the camera for a few minutes you learn where to hold it and problem fixed. Great gift for anyone who loves to take pictures and great for low lighing. I recommend to everyone!

Reviews.Title: exceptional clarity, phenomenal video
Reviews.Author: Michael Woodcock
Reviews.Content: The clarity of the pictures is exceptional. The zoom is very good. The speed of the camera is the best of any digital I have seen. The movie mode is rather impressive. True HD even on a 52" TV. I have had it a few weeks, and it works well and takes great pictures. Every camera has their own annoyances. On this one the pop up flash is it. If you hold it with two hands your left index finger has very little room to hold or it blocks the pop up flash. And this is not a tiny pocket camera. It is a bit larger, but it will fit in a pocket, just not as easily. I would give it 5 stars if not for the pop up flash. It is more of a professional camera than a consumer camera. Very impressed.

Reviews.Title: S8100 has very poor quality control
Reviews.Author: Mountain Dewd
Reviews.Content: I didn't buy it here, but I feel I should share my experience with the unit I purchased (and returned) elsewhere.The camera came with some great features, but what motivated me to buy it were the comments about fast response and low light image quality.  When I got mine and started shooting with it, I wondered if I read reviews about the same camera.  The image quality was terrible, and very inconsistent.  In the rare chance that I got a decent shot, only the center was focused, and the image defocused very quickly towards the sides.  I think the left side was a little worse than the right.  Furthermore, the image also became noisy outside of the central regions, especially near the edges.  The noise sort of reminded me of too much jpeg compression, but it's not quite the same.  Also, the images had a lot of distortions away from the center.  This is outdoors in good lighting.  I'm guessing my unit had a lens problem.  Indoors with lower lighting, the images are even worse without flash, and over exposed with flash.  So I am not seeing where the improved low light quality is.Another problem is some slop in the zoom control.  If I push the zoom either way and release, the zoom action will overshoot a little.  So it's hard to get it to the exact zoom level needed to frame the subject.I have an old Coolpix 3200 with 3.2 megapixel capability, and it takes much better pictures than this S8100; it consistently took sharper pictures in the proper lighting without any of the image anomalies that the s8100 produced.  Sure, in low light, the 3200 images are noisy, but that is expected.  Its other big problem is that its responses are too slow.  So I was hoping to find a replacement with faster response and better low light imaging.  The S8100 unit I got failed on both accounts, so I returned it the same evening.

Reviews.Title: Great for the Price
Reviews.Author: pcpatter
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in the RED color to replace my old Canon A1100 IS. The 10x optical zoom really is amazing, as is the focus capability. My main complaint with my Canon was any picture taken using the self-timer was out of focus. Not so with the Nikon! I even used the Nikon to take a picture in complete darkness. It came out looking great! Focused and well-lit. Needless to say I was super impressed with the image quality and versatility. All the different customizable shot options really cover your bases. My only complaints about the camera are the location of the pop-up flash and the USB port cover. The rubber cover is held on so shoddily, I can certainly see it breaking off in the near future.

Reviews.Title: Re-think this before you purchase!
Reviews.Author: kates
Reviews.Content: Another fatal error with the Nikon Coolpix S8100!  Camera was being enjoyed until it decided to lock up while on vacation.  Upon returning home, I sent the camera to Nikon for repair (no reimbursement for mailing expenses) and heard nothing for three weeks.  Camera was returned to me without any of the necessary repairs.  Nikon enclosed a notice stating that "we initially indicated we would be able to service your product.  Unfortunately, after attempting to repair it, we have found your product is beyond economical repair due to WATER DAMAGE."  This is absolute bull**** as my camera has never even been near water in the seven months that I've had it! (I live in the midwest prairie and have only traveled to arrid places since owning this particular camera). I immediately called the 800 number to complain and spoke with an agent that could not seem to understand why I was so upset. I requested to speak with her supervisor and was put on indefinite hold.  While on hold, I was conveniently disconnected.  I do not understand how a company such as Nikon can make these false claims to get out of repairing one of their products that shouldn't even have issues just seven months into owning!  I have tried repeatedly to get this corrected, but appears that this camera was just made for the trash.Whatever you do....buy any brand other than the Nikon.  I wish now that I'd originally purchased the Canon or Panasonic that I'd shopped.  At least I'll know what NOT to buy this time around.P.S.  Even prior to it's death, the camera was not what I had expected.  While fun and simple to use, the flash is poorly located; the telephoto does not meet basic expectations, and the camera only accepts 3 or 4 memory card brands.

Reviews.Title: Review:  Nikon S8100 vs. Canon S95
Reviews.Author: N. Chawla "neerajc"
Reviews.Content: I just tried both these models for 2 days - borrowed it from a friend (Thanks Jig!). I've owned Canons for about 10 years (SLRs, P&S; models), and have been looking for a P&S; camera that would take good videos - especially indoors - have low light sensitivity and have a big zoom (at least 7x or higher). Here are my comparison points - both are quite disappointing with pluses showing strengths and minuses showing weaknesses/issues. You decide what works for you based on your requirements. I'm keeping price out as a comparison datapoint.Nikon S8100 Review+ Superb resolution of screen+ Can zoom while shooting video (in and out) - the camera retains focus - slow, but gets there - indoors has a lot of trouble finding focus while zooming in/out- Videos inside the house even with many light bulbs on are very dark - almost unusable at times - poor quality+ Colors both inside and outside in light are very accurate - much more than S95+ 10x is a fantastic zoom for shooting stills or videos- battery life poor- no external charger - have to connect it to computer to charge (do they sell separate charger?)+ flash is one of the brightest I've seen in a Point and Shoot - excellent!+ Press a button for shooting video - ever ready mode- Pressing the record button to 'stop' recording takes a while- Camera crashed on me once with an error message - I had to remove battery to reboot- Can hear all sorts of motor noises/sounds while camera is even trying to find focus - when you zoom in/out, you can hear motor sounds+ even though its not a fast lens (f2.0), the low light sensitivity is quite good - must be the CMOS sensorCanon S95 Review- Overall underwhelmed by this camera - I've been a big fan (and prior owner) of the S series and have owned 2 Canon SLR's+ Good low light sensitivity to pictures indoors+ Videos indoors are very usable due to sensitivity of sensor- Garish colors at times - I can't believe a camera with the internals of the G12 is confused with colors in the Auto WB setting- Poor resolution of screen compared to Nikon (half the resolution)- Poor job of color accuracy - struggles with CF bulbs and cloudy skies - too much yellow or blue tints+ can shoot in RAW hence can do lossless editing in Lightroom or Photoshop- big negative - can't keep focus once you start zooming in while shooting a video- separate dial mode to get to for shooting video+ zooming in and out are slow but can't hear motor sounds while shooting video- 4x is minor zoom - most cameras have a lot more these days

Reviews.Title: broke after 2 months!
Reviews.Author: Ann
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as a Christmas present for my husband, meant to be a replacement for a 5 year old Canon Powershot.  We have 2 small children and the shutter speed had been an issue on the older camera, so we were hoping this would be an upgrade- unfortunately the speed was not much faster.  Also, after 2 months the lens cover stopped opening when we turned on the power rendering the camera unusable.  I wish it had broken a month earlier so that I could just return it to Amazon but now we have to deal directly with Nikon, which has been a pain.  This camera was way too expensive to have such poor quality!

Reviews.Title: Best Pictures At ISO200
Reviews.Author: NotaSecondTime
Reviews.Content: I read the Cnet review of this camera and there findings agree with mine. All pictures are in focus, even fast ones. Excellent color and white balance. Initial shot lag is very low. Night scenes are a standout.The picture is a touch (remember I'm very fussy) soft viewed on a 2560*1600 30" LG display. You must do three things to be blown away by the image quality: set the iso 200, set the color temperature presets and use the 12-star compression setting, just as the Cnet reviewer states. Auto color mode will under saturate and result in dull color. These three settings are magical as the pixel performance approaches my $1600 two year old Nikon D300.Being a perfectionist, I then sharpen up the image just a bit along with the integrated Noise Ninja. No purple fringing, like with Fuji. :)In actual practice long exposure come out remarkably clear, like inside of a supermarket. People may be blurry but the products on the shelf are sharp. My $500 Panasonic LX1 has difficulty focusing, blurry with lots of noise under identical conditions. A remarkable value for the size, convenience and meager price.Inexpensive replacement batteries and AC charging kit here at Amazon, I used them for several days and they seem to work fine. Here is what I ordered to create my own kit:PouchGTMax Durable Digital Camera Carrying Pouch Nylon Case with Strap- Black/Blue for Canon PowerShot SX210 IS, Nikon COOLPIX S8100, COOLPIX S80, COOLPIX P7000, COOLPIX S1100pj, COOLPIX S5100, Kodak ZxD, EasyShare C195, PLAYTOUCH Video Camera, EasyShare C14...A/C and Car Battery ChargerCTA MR-ENEL12 Mini Battery Charger Kit for Nikon EN-EL12 BatteryBatteryHigh Capacity EN-EL12 Replacement Lithium-Ion Battery for Nikon CoolPix S610 S610c S710 S630 S620 Digital CameraSDHC Memory CardPNY Professional 16 GB Class 10 Hi-Speed SDHC 20MB/s 133x Flash Memory Card P-SDHC16G10-EF (Black)Professional Color Temperature Measurement Mode-----------------------------------------------Overall Nikon has streamlined and automated the menu to make the camera easy and fast to use. The high resolution screen is great for showing color casts from incorrect white balance. In these cases the 8100 allows enthusiasts to dynamically set custom color temperature. Simply select the "PRE" Preset manual in the White balance menu. Find a grey or white object in the scene and let the camera measure and set the optimal white balance. Sweet!Last night I went to an upscale outside mall with many shops have their own type of lighting. This MANUAL feature was essential to prevent color casts.The PRE mode may not work with night-scene mode. I don't know yet.Bring Out the Shadow Details----------------------------The high resolution screen also show areas of the picture with not enough light. The 8100's D-Lighting feature comes to the rescue by allows the photographer to post process and create a second stored picture with increased black level. Pick the one to keep later.ConsNo RAW format. Did not test video.All in all a GREAT pocket camera. Certainly better than the 8000 model, which is still top-rated in 1/2011 Consumer Reports magazine.

Reviews.Title: Great Point & Shoot Camera
Reviews.Author: Congzilla "Congzilla"
Reviews.Content: To start off I wish I was able to give it 4.5 stars.I won't waste time with too in depth of a review as there are already plenty of them.  This is a great compact point and shoot camera.  The image quality is amazing, and more importantly the focus time is much quicker than most cameras in this category.  I did adjust a few of the setting for the auto mode to get increased consistency and more true to life images.  The main adjustment to make is in the resolution, the default is 1080, I moved it to 1080*. I also upped the rgb one notch toward red as well as the vividness it one or two notches depending on lighting.I mention the settings I have changed because it seems like people complaining about fuzzy images simply do not know how to use even a basic point and shoot camera. The only fuzzy images I have gotten were from testing the continuous shooting mode, and once I learned how to use the mode correctly I got great images with it.The only complaint I have with this camera is the video.  The video itself is fantastic and crisp with smooth playback.  The issue is with the audio.  It clearly picks up all of the tick tick sounds of the the lens as it focuses.  It is VERY noticeable and renders the beautiful looking video just about useless.  Since like most people I got the camera for the still images this is a minor annoyance but still enough to keep it from being perfect. Though it is still better (yes even the audio) than the Flip (any generation) or Kodak Zi8 & Zi10 for video.

Reviews.Title: Nikon s8100
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: I have used this camera for about two weeks now and I love this camera.  This picture and video quality are superb.  Lens quality is amazing with a 10x (300m) zoom and a nice wide angle 30m minimum focal length.  Quick to turn on and take a picture or just a moment pause before starting video capture. This is the workhorse of a point and shoot camera. You can also take pictures during videoing.This camera is a bit bulkier than the average compact camera, but worth the size due to all the features.  I can still put the camera in my pocket without too much bulk. Recommend a SD card with at least a class 4 rating (the 1080p is a a lot of data to write). I like the fact that I can just plug the camera into the charger instead of removing the battery all the time. Highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: A Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Shu
Reviews.Content: All the good things that others reviewers mentioned. The video is better than expected. Really easy to use whether taking videos or just pictures. I did hear the click sound when I switched to tracking mode but went away after switching to another scene or auto. The macro is useful for me. Overall, I would recommend it. A suggestion to get a bigger SD card like 32 GB if full HD video is preferred.

Reviews.Title: What's in the box...?
Reviews.Author: sodakar
Reviews.Content: As a long-time Canon user, I opened the box and was surprised at the lack of a dedicated battery charger.  I will confess I didn't go out of my way to check, and assumed it was included.Since Amazon doesn't list what's in the box, I'll list it here:- manual- wrist strap- software- AV cable- USB to AV cable (aka charging cable)- EH-68P AC-to-USB adapter- EN-EL12 battery- and of course, the cameraEvery Canon camera I've owned for the last 10 years has always come with a dedicated, compact, wall-mount, battery charger with a flip-out AC plug, eg: CB-2LB.  The Nikon 8100 came with an AC-to-USB adapter (EH-68P) and a USB-to-miniAV cable, which forces you to charge the battery INSIDE the camera.I don't think I'm in the minority when I say that I generally dislike having downtime on my camera while charging.  I also don't like having to pop out some plastic/rubberized tab on the camera and stick in a proprietary cable repeatedly, which eventually leads to a broken cable or broken port.  What's worse -- the AV cable port is on the bottom, which means that your camera can't even sit upright when charging -- it has be to be placed on its lens or its LCD.  Far from ideal.I completely don't understand why this would make sense on an electronic device that has an easily removable battery.  Perhaps this could be a cost-savings move on the part of Nikon, but at the point they're shipping you an AC-to-USB adapter, they're not saving a bundle.Of course, you can buy the Nikon MH-65, which is a dedicated battery charger, but you'll notice I didn't say "compact", or "wall-mount", or "flip-out AC plug", as none apply.  The MH-65 does not mount directly on the wall, but comes with a long AC cord and a slot to insert your battery.  Not gigantic, but far from compact, if you include the cord.  The MH-61 is a wall mount that was designed correctly (albeit for a different series), but starting with the MH-62 up to the MH-65, Nikon has abandoned the wall-mount capability in favor of an AC cable.  Perhaps too many people were electrocuting themselves on the fold-out AC plug?  I have no idea.With a compact, wall mount charger, you can pop the camera in one pocket, and the compact charger and buy a spare battery for your other pocket, and you're an instant road warrior / vacation photographer / etc.  With the Nikon, you're now stuck carrying a cord as well, which adds considerably to the bulk.  Sure, you can look around on eBay for a generic charger with a flip-out AC adapter, but I would be a bit concerned about the quality of said charger.  It'll probably be fine, but with Li-ion batteries that can incinerate when overcharged, it makes me think twice about whether or not I'm willing to trust a generic charger.All that being said, the Nikon 8100 came in at 2/3rd the cost of the Canon 4500 (at least for me - your mileage may vary), and even with the annoyances surrounding the battery charger, it's an incredible camera for the size and cost.  I would recommend this camera to a beginner who dreams of DSLR-quality shots, but is not willing to put in the necessary hours (and hours) to hone one's skills, as well as the minimum ~$1000 one needs to get a decent body, flash, and lens.  This is just my opinion, but these compacts are good enough and smart enough to allow a complete beginner to get a better shot in difficult conditions than a beginner-intermediate user with a DSLR.Minus 0.5 star for a noisy zoom lens and antiquated interface.  Minus 0.5 star for not only not including a wall charger, but not even making one available for purchase.  Overall, 4 stars for an incredibly great camera for the price.

Reviews.Title: No battery charger.  No manual.  No action mode.
Reviews.Author: Historken
Reviews.Content: I just got this camera so this isn't a review based on much experience but what I have is most disappointing.  I simply want people to note a major omission that I didn't detect in the reviews I read.  The only way to charge the battery and the extra one I bought (only good for 200 pictures on a charge) is to use a charger block, cord, and connection directly to the camera.  It ties up the camera for hours. It's also difficult to connect compared with popping a battery out and using a charger.  A second party does manufacture a battery charger that I have ordered.  Be careful which one you get because one of the units "often purchased with" doesn't work with this camera.  I found that out from one of the one star reviews.There is really only one setting for general use, and that one is full auto.  You can shut off the flash, but it ignores your selection in most modes and that awkwardly placed flash pops up right where you naturally grip the camera.  This is the first camera I have ever had that didn't have a mode for action photographs.  It has a perfectly worthless "sports burst" if you can find your way to it.  It has one for "museum" and "night landscape" and other such seldom used choices.  This is not a serious photographer's "backup camera."Oh yes, there is no manual included,  but you can get a PDF version online that is the same as what is on the DVD.  In either case, it's worthless when you are out shooting with this as a new camera unless you have a photographic memory.  (This camera's complexity demands a manual.)  At least that was made known in the reviews.  The camera is not nearly as intuitive as my Canon Elph and is much harder to hold properly, and it, of course, has no viewfinder.  Also, unlike others, I'm underwhelmed by the display which is pretty dim indoors while shooting.UPDATE  I still find this camera inferior to my Canon Elph.  Also, every flash picture I take renders a washed out light toned picture.  My goldendoodle looks like a white dog and she really is "golden."

Reviews.Title: Broken within 10 months, and flash error every now and then
Reviews.Author: Yu He "elysee"
Reviews.Content: First of all, I am really a big Nikon fan. I have been using Nikon for over 20 years, even before digital SLR came out. I have own so many Nikon cameras and had quite pleasant experiences, when it comes to choose a point and shoot, my first choice of course is a Nikon.I used three Nikon point and shoot till now, 2 of them broke both with the message "Lens Error". Basically it's impossible to turn on/off, looks like the lens got stuck somewhere. -- While I searched online, there are so many people got the same kind of problem, all suggesting weird ways of making it work again. Unfortunately, none of the tricks worked on my *error* camera.So I sent it back to Nikon, thinking it should at least be covered by warranty, given that I only bought it for 10 months. In the end, no, it's not covered, and the repair cost is half of what the camera is worth.Another thing is, after about 2 months I got the camera, it started to have message telling me the flash light is not fully on or something, even if I push down the flash and retry it over and over again. Just when I was thinking to return it,  this error just magically disappeared, so I kept it all the way till 8 months later, when it broke, completely, and cannot be repaired under warranty.So, I don't know what to say.The picture quality is good for a point and shoot, the video quality is also very nice. I guess what I'm trying to say is, this is a nice camera, when it lasts.If you are ok with changing your point and shoot camera every year or so, this could be a good choice. Otherwise, go with something steadier.As for me, it's time to look at other point and shoot and say farewell to Nikon, well, at least to the point and shoot type.

Reviews.Title: Camera lasted exactly 8 months
Reviews.Author: Judy in Pacific NW
Reviews.Content: After 6 months I started getting card errors, and it wouldn't display some images. I changed cards but have the same issues. At 8 months, when I turn it off, the lens retracts but the shutter won't close. I get an error message and it won't let me turn it off or back on. I have to manually close the little shutter cover and then I can use it again. For the money I spent, I'm REALLY unhappy.UPDATE on Nov 7, 2011: I took the camera back in to Best Buy. Since it was under a year old the manufacturer warrenty was still in place. They sent it off to be fixed and within 3 weeks I had my camera back. It is working fine so far.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, until it stopped working
Reviews.Author: Burton J. Loupee III "Faceeater"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera 7 days ago. I really liked it and was finally getting into to the point where I could switch back and forth between settings, and could anticipate what setting I'd need for the best picture. I took picture 384 then tried to turn the camera off. I got a lens error and the lens would not retract. I didn't want to force it in, so I tried to power down and back up, but nothing I tried fixed the lens error. I finally ended up returning after I looked a bit online and noticed that this was a common problem. Overall I liked it and wished that it would have worked out.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic camera
Reviews.Author: Basil Betty
Reviews.Content: I'm a bargain shopper.  It seems the past 3-4 years I have always purchased whatever point-and-shoot camera is on sale on Black Friday and I am always displeased with it within several months of usage and then buy another one the next year.  This year I came to terms with the "you get what you pay for" sentiment and decided I would buy a GOOD camera because it is worth the extra $50 or $100 to have the fantastic quality.  I'm not a professional photographer, nor do I spend hours on my computer editing photos & video.  I'm a mom of two small children, I work full-time and I'm a grad student - I don't have time to spend making my pictures better with software.  I wanted to be able to take great pictures of my family and friends, etc. at various events and be able to print them right then & there without any editing.  This camera is it.  The backlighting feature and the night shot feature is AWESOME!!!!!  It's great for those school programs when the lighting is dark.  And the zoom is incredible!! I just got back from taking pics at my daughter's Christmas program and all of my other cameras I've had there's no way I could get a good close-up shot, they would always be blurry.  This one I could zoom right up to her face and it was crystal clear.  I love this camera!  It is easy to use, great features, and compact so you can still tote it around everywhere you go.  I definitely recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Unacceptable Reliability
Reviews.Author: Diane
Reviews.Content: My Nikon S8100 failed on the second day of use after about 20 shots with a fatal lens error. The lens wouldn't retract and the power stayed on with a "Lens Error" message on the screen. Taking the battery out as to try reset it didn't work. I am positive the lens wasn't bumped while it was extended so it is just an unreliable mechanism. This is really too bad because the camera has so many great features and works for 95% of the photos I want to take. This camera replaced an S8000 I got a little more than a year ago that has most of the identical features and it took great photos too until the lens wouldn't retract with the same "Lens Error" message. Since it is just past the one year warranty, it too is junk. My S8100 is being returned to Amazon for a refund as I have to give up on Nikon. This is really too bad, but their reputation is shot. The failure of this S8100 was also at a very bad time as it is at the beginning of time with grandsons from the Mid West. Since I loved the quality of photos of the S8000, I thought the S8100 might have better quality besides some upgrades tot eh focal plane, better dark performance, etc., so I purchased one anyway even with all the bad luck others have had with this camera. I can now say with first hand information, that Nikon is now making JUNK. Thus, the one star as there isn't a zero star rating.

Reviews.Title: Stopped working after a month
Reviews.Author: NN
Reviews.Content: I have always been a big Nikon fan -- so I was so excited to see this camera and could not wait to buy and use it. I successfully used it for a few weeks and then one day the viewfinder just went black and it completely stopped working.  I am very disappointed in this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera (WHEN IT WORKS)
Reviews.Author: psyberhenry "psyberhenry"
Reviews.Content: Bought the camera in March - it stopped working two months later (LENS ERROR) and I had to send it in for repairs (at my expense).  Two weeks later, I call Nikon's repairs department for a status update and discover that the parts to fix it are on backorder for another month. [EDITING REVIEW] - We ended up getting the camera back, fixed, two days after I wrote this review.  So - we definitely have a better feeling about Nikon than we did when we wrote the review - hopefully, we won't have problems with the camera after this.I wish there was recourse for returning it and getting my money back - a lemon law?  At this point unless they somehow manage to make this right, we're not going to buy Nikon again.

Reviews.Title: S8100 Coolpix
Reviews.Author: rlg1991
Reviews.Content: Purchased this camera a few months ago. Was shipped fast and I loved it at first, great zoom and very clear pictures. I went on vacation about about 15 days later I was using the camera and suddenly the lens become stuck and the screen stated a lens error. Nothing became stuck in the lens but because of such a large zoom something in the lens acually broke. I called nikon and lets just say my camera was not fixed.

Reviews.Title: No high-speed-shutter scene mode
Reviews.Author: GeezingInVA
Reviews.Content: This purchase was to replace my aging trusty Sony DSC-T30B subcompact I've used for travel when I choose to not carry my Nikon D90 dSLR and gear. (The Sony had begun to show dust on the sensor, and since the camera is a sealed unit, I can't correct the dust without sending it away to Sony for an out-of-warranty repair, and I was getting tired of correcting/cloning the dust bunnies in post processing). I thought I'd thoroughly researched replacement brands/models, and this Nikon S8100 was my best choice.Pros: Terrific form factor, brilliant LCD screen, 10x optical zoom, usual Nikon quality, support, warranty.Cons: No high-speed-shutter scene mode, which makes this unacceptable for my travel camera. Not being able to force a high shutter speed without jumping through hoops (pushing ISO and then remembering to put it back to "normal", or using "Motion Detection" which unfortunately is disabled for any ISO other than "Auto", or using one of the Burst modes which forces a 1M or 5M down-sized capture depending on which burst mode),... limits its usefulness for me when shooting photos from a moving ship, boat, auto, coach, etc., or when handing it to someone to take a snapshot... even in full Auto mode. I'm not expecting full shutter-priority, but having a high-speed-shutter scene setting was more critical to me than some of the other presets, like a "Food" preset.The S8100 is the first digital camera I've owned that forces you to charge the battery inside the camera. That makes having a spare battery a minimal benefit since you can't charge one battery while using the other in the camera. The very flimsy cover over the charging/power socket might be an issue over time due to stress fatigue.Unfortunately, I was never able to work out the high-speed-shutter issue, so this otherwise terrific Nikon was  returned for a refund.

Reviews.Title: Very low quality & horrific customer service!
Reviews.Author: icewiz30
Reviews.Content: I do not typically write reviews but I had to on this camera after my horrific experience with Nikon.  I had the S8100 for just over 3 months and experienced a lens error.  I sent it back because this issue is usually covered under warranty, but because it had a little dent on the bottom they said the error was contributed to physical damage and was no longer under warranty.This was utter crap and a way for Nikon to get around paying for the costs to fix the camera.Who doesn't have a dent on their camera?I got a new one and that one broke 2 months after as well.All in all, this is not well-built product and Nikon's customer service is horrible.With all of the cameras out there, spend your money on something else and not Nikon!  And you may see this review on other websites, but I feel that I need to warn others about Nikon and am willing to take the time to deliver this message.

Reviews.Title: Good camera but terrible customer service
Reviews.Author: M. Williams "avid reader"
Reviews.Content: I've owned an S8100 for a year, and I've been very satisfied with the pictures. However I will never buy a Nikon product again. My camera broke, and I followed all the procedures on their website to return it to the service center. The reply that I got from then indicated that no one had paid any attention to the paperwork that I'd included in the package. When I called to follow up, it took over 2 weeks for them to track down the materials I had sent in. When I asked to speak to a customer service manager, I waited on hold for 30 mins. I got the distinct impression that they were avoiding having to deal with a real customer. And this is their so-called Customer Service Center! I finally hung up frustrated, and determined to let others know of my bad experience. Nikon? Never again.

Reviews.Title: Lens Error Strikes Again
Reviews.Author: Clifford Hull
Reviews.Content: I really love the size, feel and capabilities - excellent zoom and functions, but after only about 7 weeks of use, this camera lens locked and I got the "lens error" message - while on the second day of my vacation in Austria.  Sent to Nikon and I'm still waiting after a month in their shop.  In the meantime, I've missed having the camera for my family vacation - ugh!  I suspect they have a backlog on the the part as this appears to be a common problem.  Really want to like Nikon but not sure I can buy from them again.

Reviews.Title: Alaskan Nightmare
Reviews.Author: Pat O. Clifton
Reviews.Content: My brand new Nikon 8100s suffered the fatal lens error one week into our Alaska vacation. The camera was not dropped or "banged." It just quit working. The pictures and video I recovered from the memory card were great! Too bad the 8100s all too often has lens failure. I will stick with my much less expensive Sony cybershot. FYI the videos we took with the inexpensive Kodak "flip" type camera turned out great! ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: As I feared Nikon has refused to repair the camera under warranty even though it was only six months old. Nikon sent one email saying they would fix the camera for free and then a few days later sent me another email saying it would cost over $100.00 to repair. So much for registering warranty information and carefully mailing the camera to their California repair facility. If you call tech support, you will talk to some nice Indian who will say they are very sorry but that is the way it is.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera and HD vid camera
Reviews.Author: Max
Reviews.Content: I researched this Nikon Coolpix S8100 camera against the Canon Powershot SD4500 IS (aka IXUS 1000).  This camera replaces my previous Canon Powershot Sd750 Digital Elph. The SD750 was a fine camera and served me well. But it was inadequate for any decent video recording.  But I was very familiar with the Canon menus and design, and enjoyed the layout and look and feel of the Canon. In the end, I went with the Nikon Coolpix S8100 over the Canon SD4500 for a few key reasons: First, the research and reviews indicated that the Canon may be better suited for video recording but the Nikon holds the edge for the photography. And the Canon menus were supposedly better navigable than the Canon.Here are my first impressions: The very-lightly rubberized/texturized feel of the Nikon is superior to the Canon. This camera feels like a robust, serious, all-business professional camera, vs. Canon feels more like a cute, artsy, fun, weekender camera. I got the Nikon in the red finish, which looks absolutely amazing and gorgeous. The menus are very easy to navigate, and I felt right at home. I did not feel like I was missing out from having switched to the Nikon, from the Canon. The backlighting feature is amazing - I had taken countless indoor portrait pictures with my old Canon that were no good because of backlighting (this is when the subject appears all "black" or washed out/shadowed when you take the picture near a window with sunlight coming in, indoors). The video recording is very, very nice, and full 1080p, no doubt.  I purchased a Lexar Class 10 SDHC 32GB 133x write speed card ($75) as the memory card.  The 10x optical zoom is simply amazing - it presents a huge opportunity for weekend and fun photography.The things I mind, but can live with (cons):  While you are recording video, you can *definitely* hear (and it will get recorded) the sound of the zoom lens motor, especially if you are zooming in/out all the way. But it's not the end of the world or a showstopper. If there is other sound that is part of your recording, you will be fine. If there is NO OTHER sound (it's a quiet recording), then yes, if you are zooming in/out, you will hear that, when you play back your recording.I also bought a spare battery and separate charger, so I don't have to "tie up" the camera in order to charge a battery.I give this camera a 10/10 -- it meets/exceeds my expectations.

Reviews.Title: GREAT camera! Once you learn the right settings, and it doesn't take long!
Reviews.Author: mitchwendy
Reviews.Content: After researching cameras for a while, I finally decided to pick this one over all the rest.For the price point, its JAMPACKED with features and takes GREAT shots! Close ups are amazing, the Zoom feature works great, and its pretty intuitive to use.I was a little nervous when I read some of the negative reviews, but once I got the camera in my hand, realized it was a matter of those reviewers not using the proper settings. Its not hard to glance over a few pages in the owners manual, and find out what setting you should use for what situation. There are so many "helps" on this thing, you HAVE to take great pics! Backlighting help,  "night assist", the HDR type feature (where it takes 3 shots and combines them to one), the various sport modes, and the variant number of pics it'll take in succession are fun to play with and guarantee you'll get the shot you want!I am really glad I bought this!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: rhm
Reviews.Content: Overall image quality is not that great. I was hoping that this camera would produce better than average low light photos. It does not.They are frequently fuzzy and a bit out of focus. Although the camera is quicker than most point and shoots,  the flash slows it down. The flash also seems too bright, often over exposing the nearest object in the pictures.

Reviews.Title: I blame mysefl
Reviews.Author: Winelover "Wine lover"
Reviews.Content: I probably should have waited for more reviews, but I got caught up in the hype surrounding this one.  I took this on a trip to Costa Rica and the number of shots I missed because it wouldn't focus is depressing.  So many great pics got away... beautiful frogs on a leaf... the focus would be fine, and then go out.  Since there is no manual override, I lost out.  The LCD screen is great at night; terrible in bright sunlight... couldn't see the spider monkeys in the screen, so couldn't get the pictures.  And then there is the shutter lag problem.  I could go on, but suffice it to say I would return it if I could, but it's now been two months.  I just bought a P100... the compromise on a compact is fine for e.g., family pictures, but not worth it for nature pictures.

Reviews.Title: HUGE Waste of Money
Reviews.Author: Prez
Reviews.Content: Like many others who bought this camera, I am extremely disappointed with the product and with Nikon's customer service.  I bought this camera at a camera store, and based my decision solely on the recommendation of the seemingly knowledgeable salesman.  I was never impressed with the quality of the photos - it seemed quite difficult to get clear shots, which was never a problem on our old digital camera.Eight months into ownership, the shutter got stuck half-way open (sound familiar to other reviews?) so I took it back to the camera store.  They sent it off to Nikon and four weeks later I got the camera back, having missed the opportunity to take pictures of school celebrations and summer camps.  Shortly after its return, I noticed that the image in the screen seemed to vibrate or "shiver," even when the camera was just sitting on a table.
